takeaways: Every board meeting follows a structured agenda — from call to order through public comment to adjournment.
Executive sessions are closed to the public but strictly limited to topics defined in ORS (e.g., personnel, litigation, real estate).
Public comment is a right — boards must provide opportunity, but can set reasonable time limits.
Board members should avoid discussing board business outside of properly noticed public meetings.

knowledgeCheck.question: Executive sessions can be used to discuss any topic the board considers sensitive.
knowledgeCheck.explanation: Executive sessions are limited to specific topics defined by Oregon law (ORS 192.660), such as personnel matters, litigation, and real property transactions.

knowledgeCheck.question: What is a consent agenda?
options: An agenda that all members have agreed to in advance
A group of routine items approved with a single vote
A list of topics for executive session
An agenda prepared by the superintendent alone
knowledgeCheck.explanation: A consent agenda groups routine, non-controversial items (like approval of minutes) to be approved with a single vote, saving meeting time for substantive discussion.
